Expert Videos One of the weaknesses of cellphone cameras is the ability to shoot in telephoto mode. This was shot with a digital Canon camera and enlarged without losing detail or crispness. Susan Breslow Sardone. 
Click! If there's one thing a traveler doesn't want to forget to bring on a honeymoon, it's a camera — and there's nothing more fun and functional than a digital one. Why Can't I Just Use the Camera in My Smartphone? 
Even if your smartphone, with its built-in camera, may never be far from your hand and you've built quite a photo library of selfies and destination shots, it may let you down on your honeymoon — and those are images you can never recreate. 
The problems with cellphone cameras are that: Both the shutter speed and the focal distance are preset. While that is fine for most photos, a shooter has little flexibility and creativity Digital telephoto shots create pixilated images — and forget about making enlargements. They'll look blurry at best What's So Great About Digital Cameras? 
Flexibility. Creativity. Telephoto lenses. Better night shots. And resolution is higher than ever, while prices have come down (although not as low as we'd like to see them). You can record video with most digital camera models and many now are wi-fi-compatible so you can upload from the road. 
As a traveler and photographer, the brand of camera that I consistently choose is Canon. The company features a wide range of products from couldn't-be-simpler point-and-shoot digital camera models to high-end models with powerful zoom lenses. Researching a Top Digital Camera for a Traveler 
When it's time to buy a new digital camera, I start by asking other travelers what they recommend. Then I research online. As a traveler, what I look for primarily is a camera that is lightweight yet powerful. I want one that will take the best photos in the most situations and has a good zoom function.
